answers.title: How to add Python libraries to Docker image

answers.body_markdown:
There are multiple options:

*   Get into the container and install dependencies (be aware that this changes will be lost when recreating the container):

    ```
    docker exec <your-container-id> /bin/bash
    ```

    That should open an interactive bash. Then install the dependencies (pip or conda).

*   Another alternative, is to add it during build time (of the image). That is adding the instruction `RUN` into a Dockerfile

All dependencies are installed using python default tools (i.e: pip, conda)
answers.title: How to add Python libraries to Docker image

answers.body_markdown:
To customize an image you generally want to create a new one using the existing image as a base. In Docker it is extremely common to create custom images when existing ones don't quite do what you want. By basing your images off public ones you can add your own customizations without having to repeat (or even know) what the base image does.

1.  Add the necessary steps to a new **Dockerfile**.

    ```
    FROM tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-gpu-jupyter

    RUN <extra install steps>
    COPY <extra files>
    ```

    `RUN` and `COPY` are examples of instructions you might use. `RUN` will run a command of your choosing such as `RUN pip install matplotlib`. `COPY` is used to add new files from your machine to the image, such as a configuration file.

2.  Build and tag the new image. Give it a new name of your choosing. I'll call it `my-customized-tensorflow`, but you can name it anything you like.

    Assuming the `Dockerfile` is in the current directory, run `docker build`:

    ```
    $ docker build -t my-customized-tensorflow .
    ```

3.  Now you can use `my-customized-tensorflow` as you would any other image.

    ```
    $ docker run my-customized-tensorflow
    ```
answers.title: How to add Python libraries to Docker image

answers.body_markdown:
The issue typically happens when the deployment overwrites an existing service version which receives traffic (i.e. the service version is not changed). From [Deploying an app][1]:

> **Note**: If you deploy a version that specifies the same version ID as a version that already exists on App Engine, the files that you
> deploy will overwrite the existing version. This can be problematic if
> the version is serving traffic because traffic to your application
> might be disrupted. You can avoid disrupting traffic if you deploy
> your new version with a different version ID and then move traffic to
> that version.

As long as a service version is deployed and not deleted or overwritten its respective static assets remain accessible.

To prevent the issue always deploy using a fresh service version, then (gradually) migrate traffic to the newly deployed version. Keeping the latest N service versions around will give you those N sets of static assets you desire.

In general, this deployment practice is good/recommended for a few other reasons:

- avoids potential outages, see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40192557/continuous-integration-deployment-delivery-on-google-app-engine-too-risky/40193364#40193364
- avoids potential traffic loss while GAE spins up enough new version instances to handle the traffic load, see 2nd half of https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45332283/gae-shutdown-or-restart-all-the-active-instances-of-a-service-app/45335739#45335739

Potentially of interest: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48319789/google-frontend-retention-between-deployments/48332694#48332694


  [1]: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/python/tools/uploadinganapp#deploying_an_app
answers.title: Google App Engine - keep previous version's static files

answers.body_markdown:
Deploy using the `--no-promote`  flag, and utilize the [Traffic Migration][2] feature in the Standard Environment to gradually migrate traffic over to the new version so that all users don't experience an immediate switchover the moment the new version goes live. App Engine will host both the old and new versions (or, "blue" and "green") for a period of time until all traffic points to the new version, and then the old version will be shut down.

See also:

 - [Testing on App Engine][3]
 - [Migrating and Splitting Traffic with the Admin API][4]
 - [Blue-Green Deployment Pattern][1]


  [1]: https://martinfowler.com/bliki/BlueGreenDeployment.html
  [2]: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/nodejs/migrating-traffic
  [3]: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/nodejs/testing-and-deploying-your-app#testing-on-app-engine
  [4]: https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/admin-api/migrating-splitting-traffic
answers.title: Google App Engine - keep previous version's static files

answers.title: I can't seem to break out of my While loop even when it is False?

answers.body_markdown:
Your issue is caused by a logic error in the condition you're testing in your loop. You're currently testing `Player1_Tag != "X" or Player1_Tag != "0"`, which is always `True`, regardless of what `Player1_Tag` is. If the variable is equal to one of the strings, it will be not-equal to the other. Since you're joining the two comparisons with `or`, you'll never exit the loop.

You need to either join the pieces of your test with `and` instead of `or` (`Player1_Tag != "X" and Player1_Tag != "0"`), or negate the comparisons (by changing `!=` to `==`) and do a negation of the whole expression: `not (Player1_Tag == "X" or Player1_Tag == "0")`. By [De Morgan's laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Morgan%27s_laws), those are equivalent.
answers.title: I can't seem to break out of my While loop even when it is False?

answers.body_markdown:
`Player1_Tag != "X" or Player1_Tag != "0"` will *always* be true.

Consider 3 possibilities:

1. If `Player1_Tag == "X"`, then `Player1_Tag != "0"`
2. If `Player1_Tag == "0"`, then `Player1_Tag != "X"`
3. If `Player1_Tag` is anything else, it is neither `"X"` nor `"0"`.

A clearer way to write this would be `while Player1_Tag not in ("X","0"):`
answers.title: I can't seem to break out of my While loop even when it is False?

answers.body_markdown:
White lines surrounding code like that are generally indicative of something like a code linter or other similar tool giving you an indication that there might be something wrong with the code (such as not following a code convention of some sort). The code explanation is a popup showing you the arguments and documentation for whatever function or method you're working on.

Both of these things are something that Sublime doesn't do on its own; you have installed a package of some sort that provides this capability. 

If you were looking in the regular Sublime settings (`Preferences.sublime-settings`) for options that control this, they won't be there. In order to configure these away you would need to determine the package that you installed that's doing this and then configure that package not to do it or, if that's not possible, remove it.

If you use `Preferences > Package Settings > Package Control > Settings - User` from the menu, you can inspect the `installed_packages` setting to see what third party packages you installed and investigate which one of them is doing this.

Possible packages that do something like this would be `Jedi` or one of the `Anaconda` packages; essentially anything that says that it provides code support and assistance for Python is a candidate here.

Once you find the package in question, you can look in it's settings directly to see if you can turn the features you don't want off; failing that only removing the package will stop it from displaying these things.

answers.body_markdown:
As far as I am aware, the proper way to do this is with conditional compilation.

My suggestion is to write plain normal code in standard C as the default, both for maintainability and as a fall-back path that all compilers can handle. Utilize conditional compilation only as necessary to optimize for specific compilers, with a comment explaining the reason for the exception.
answers.title: How to write compiler "understandable" C code?

answers.body_markdown:
The technique used for `reverse2` is fairly idiomatic ([here][1], for example), and your own testing showed that it is properly optimized on all the systems you tested on. To make the implementation easier to understand, you can introduce more whitespace, and follow a more regular pattern.

    uint32_t reverse2(uint32_t d)
    {
        return ((d & 0x000000FFU) << 24) |
               ((d & 0x0000FF00U) << 8)  |
               ((d & 0x00FF0000U) >> 8)  |
               ((d & 0xFF000000U) >> 24) ;
    }

[Try It Online : gcc](https://tio.run/##dc0xC8IwFATg/f2KA0GaISVUB8GSMauDOEtNgi1IhSSVgvW3x7RVcenBg@PxwV0qX8eoq4CyzDHgqjV4nw784MFTOYLfwWnVtPrWGYvSB9O0Ia8lUZfKpjgHOPuwztsi@30MoychxdnQuRZZZrCG6MUUpU4sLaLYMgwT@@SfKSXEzHYMS2xEE5Nymc3oy8bRPb0oj/EN "Bash  Try It Online")

[Try It Online : clang](https://tio.run/##dc2xCsIwGATg/X@KA0GaISVUB8HSMauDOEtNgi1IhCSVgvXZY9qquPSm4/jgLrVvYlR1QFnmGKButb2C9woc/ODBUzmC38Fp1Vp167RB6YNubcibiqhLZVOcA5x5GOdNkf0WzehJSHEmdM4iyzTWEL2YIuWJpU8UW4ZhYp/8MymFmNmOYYmNaGJVtcxm9GXj6Z5elMf4Bg "Bash  Try It Online")

To your specific points:

> <sub>Are there any tips, best known methods, guidelines to write a portable C code so that the compiler would be able to detect (let's put aside the compiler bugs) the pattern and use the maximum ability of the target CPU architecture.</sub>

The key take away should be to try to write *idiomatic* code. Judging code to be *understandable* is somewhat subjective. What may seem clear to me can appear incomprehensible to someone else (and vice versa). However, there are common idioms in C programming that should be followed whenever it is appropriate to do so.

Unfortunately, I do not have at the top of my head a handy list of idioms. But, I can say I largely learned C from reading *The C Programming Language* (by K & R, of course). And I was an avid reader of *C Programming FAQs* (by Steve Summit).

However, a very good resource for C idioms can be found by reading and comprehending open source C projects, and of course the source code base of the company you work at. Following the latter has the added benefit that any code you add that follows existing conventions will naturally increase the chances of it being understood by someone else in the company.

> <sub>I often hear people say that the code has to be written so that even junior programmer would easily be able to understand it and the modern compilers are "smart" enough to take care of the optimizations. Now I have an evidence that it is not true (or at least not always true).</sub>

Compilers are just programs, so they cannot read your mind. The compiler will be programmed to look for particular patterns in the AST and apply optimizations to transform the tree into what it considers more optimal. Similarly, the peephole optimizer will look for patterns in the generated machine instructions, and then transform them into fewer equivalent instructions.

But these transformations are only possible if the generated tree or generated instructions follow a recognizable pattern. And these patterns are often determined by analyzing real-world software to see what kind of code gets generated for certain operations. If your code does not result in code that can be recognized by the compiler, you may be partially losing out on the compilers help to optimize.

Thus, another reason to try to write idiomatic C code.

Now, it can be argued that forcing oneself to write idiomatic C is a form of micro-optimization. Should you try to teach the compiler how to optimize the way you write code, or let the compiler teach you how to write code it knows how to optimize? However, the momentum is carried by the existing C programmers that write code idiomatically. New C programmers adopt these idioms for the sake of writing code more easily understood by the people that will be reviewing their code.


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/q/2182002/315052
answers.title: How to write compiler "understandable" C code?

items.title: Why do I receive an Error:Exception When Deleting py2app Using pip?

answers.body_markdown:
Below example for BigQuery Standard SQL    

    #standardSQL
    WITH `project.dataset.table` AS (
      SELECT 'HP' Product_Name, 'Implemented' status, 'Go' `language` UNION ALL

answers.body_markdown:
There's a great package called `wrapr` which has a function `let` that "allows execution of arbitrary code with substituted variable names".  The code is more verbose than using `!!`, but I find it much easier to understand and less susceptible to error.

```
df <- tibble::tribble(
  ~x, ~y, ~z,
  "a", 2, "dog",
  "b", 1, "cat",
  "a", 2,  "cat"
)

for (name in names(df)) {
  wrapr::let(
    alias = list(var = name),
    expr = {
        df %>%
          count(var) %>%
          print()
    }
  )
}
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   x         n
#>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 a         2
#> 2 b         1
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>       y     n
#>   <dbl> <int>
#> 1     1     1
#> 2     2     2
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   z         n
#>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 cat       2
#> 2 dog       1

```

answers.body_markdown:
`DeptXYZ` or any department entered manually does not exist in the database. 

`dept` has a ForeignKey relationship with `EmployeeInformation` model. Hence, to store `DeptXYZ` or any other department entered manually, the department should exist in the database. Since, `DeptXYZ` is not present in the database, Django is storing `null` instead.

To store `DeptXYZ` or any other department entered manually, you will need to create the corresponding department first. You will need to override the `form_valid()` method of `AddEmployeeInfo` as described [here][1] to create and save the manually entered department first.

Hope this help!


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/10565744/7969717

answers.body_markdown:
Because django will store the url to the image in relative format. You have to make image src to be relative url so that your mail reader can be able to read the image src.

So to solve that, you could create absolute url using [HttpRequest.build_absolute_uri][1]:

your `views.py`:

```
def view(request):
    
    imagelink = request.build_absolute_uri(user.qr_image.url)
    # ...{'first_name':user.first_name, 'imagelink': imagelink}
```

keep the rest as it is.

---

In some case you don't have request object then you could use settings to store `SERVER_URL` and you can combine `SERVER_URL` with `user.qr_image` to get the absolute url.

*settings.py*

```python
SERVER_URL="https://your-domain.com" # You could use django-environ to load this from environment variables also to be flexible when switching between environments
```

*views.py*

```
from django.conf import settings

def view(request):
    
    imagelink = settings.SERVER_URL + user.qr_image.url
    # ...{'first_name':user.first_name, 'imagelink': imagelink}
```

  [1]: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.2/ref/request-response/#django.http.HttpRequest.build_absolute_uri

answers.body_markdown:
I think there's pretty much no benefit to using something like `decodeURI()` or `escape()` which aren't meant for this. 

I would recommend passing it through something like [PostCSS][1] in order to parse the CSS first. This has multiple benefits from both a security and functionality point of view. Firstly it (should) be able to detect any syntax errors which will in turn harden you against code injection. You're relying on the security of PostCSS or whatever parser you're using but this is better than nothing. It will also makes it easier to add functionality such as debug messages or CSS prefixing in future.

For the more specific question of *'is it safe to inject CSS unescaped?'*: I will note my relatively basic investigation appears to suggest that `<style>` elements do seem to have some protection against script injection anyway, at least compared to other tags. Usually with injected code (via innerHTML) you can inject some code via doing [something like this][2]

```
<img src="/" onerror = "alert(1);">
```

However it seems that for a style tag then since it's contents will always be considered a [Text node][3], (indeed you have explictly set it to be a text node in your example) then that's not something which would appear to be possible. 

I would still definitely pass it through a parser in any case, to be sure. (I will update this answer if I find any method of executing JavaScript via a style tag).


  [1]: https://postcss.org/
  [2]: https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/60861/why-are-scripts-injected-through-innerhtml-not-executed-whilst-onerror-and-other
  [3]: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/semantics.html#the-style-element

answers.body_markdown:
> So is there a way just to test the hashes and not the date and return
> an equal or not equal result?

Yea, Powershell added some nifty cmdlets to help with that a few releases back. The following sort of what you're after?
```
$first = $(Get-FileHash -Path '.\app.js').Hash
$second = $(Get-FileHash -Path '.\hive.js').Hash
if ($first -eq $second) { Write-Output "Match" } else { Write-Output "Different" }
```

**Updated Answer Based on Comments from Requester**

Unless the file or hash algorithm selected is changed, the hash will the same each time its calculated:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

`Compare-Object` is a mechanism to compare two objects, which are composed of multiple properties. You wouldn't usually use `Compare-Object` in a case like this since you can just compare the two hash strings. Can you modify the sample I've given you to use `Compare-Object`, sure, but it's overkill. 

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/DXTT1.png

Despite that, those URLs work.  I need to get rid of that warning since it scares users needlessly.  (There is nothing on the site that could be harmful - no financial information, no medical information, nothing like that.)  This is odd because Chrome stores the certificate in exactly the same place as IE does, and if the cert is stored by Chrome IE can use it without problems.  (But not vice versa.)  

In chrome click on the red warning and it says that the certificate is invalid, but nothing in the certificate details is marked as having a problem.  Comparing the details
of the same certificate in IE and Chrome, in the same Windows supplied dialog window, oddly they differ in subtle ways.  This makes no sense to me since this is the same file, or at least it is supposed to be!  In the Details tab (all other fields are the same):

```
               IE         Chrome
Version        V3         V1
Serial Number  (hex)      2
Subject Key ID (hex)      no such field
Authority Key  (hex)      no such field
Basic Constr.  (data)     no such field
thumbprint     (hex)      (different hex)
```

I tried exporting the cert from IE and importing it into Chrome and saw the same thing as before.  It is like the two browsers interpret the cert differently.

Given how the CA and server certs were made (see below), can somebody please explain why this is happening, and how to either configure Chrome not to complain or how to make self signed certs that it will accept?  Thanks.

The CA cert was made this way:

```
openssl genpkey -algorithm RSA -out ca.key \
  -pass pass:random_string_of_characterss -pkeyopt rsa_keygen_bits:2048

openssl req -new -x509 -days 7300 -key ca.key -out ca.crt <<EOD
US
California
Pasadena
(not shown)
(not shown)
(not shown, is part of organization name)
(not shown)
EOD

```

The server cert was made with:

```
openssl genpkey -algorithm RSA -out server.key \
  -pass pass:different_random_string -pkeyopt rsa_keygen_bits:2048

openssl req -new -key server.key -out server.csr <<EOD
US
California
Pasadena
(not shown, matches CA field)
(not shown, matches CA field)
(not shown, is fully qualified IP name of machine)
(not shown, matches CA field)


EOD #the two blank lines before this are intentional

#increment the CERT
openssl x509 -req -days 7300 -in server.csr -CA ca.crt \
  -CAkey ca.key -set_serial 02 -out server.crt

cp server.key server.key.secure

openssl rsa -in server.key.secure -out server.key
#removed password
```

Note that the name of the machine, and the name used on the certificate, are
actually a DNS alias.  The primary entry is like "foo.bar.school.edu" and the one used is like "who.bar.school.edu".  They both resolve to the same IP address.  Doesn't seem like it should matter, but maybe it does?

More info...
Found this page:  
https://medium.com/@tbusser/creating-a-browser-trusted-self-signedssl-certificate-2709ce43fd15

so tried that.  

```
cat >v3.ext <<'EOD'
authorityKeyIdentifier=keyid,issuer
basicConstraints=CA:FALSE
keyUsage = digitalSignature, nonRepudiation, keyEncipherment, dataEncipherment
subjectAltName = @alt_names

[alt_names]
DNS.1 = *.bar.school.edu
DNS.2 = *.school.edu
EOD
#increment the count and use the extfile
openssl x509 -req -days 7300 -in server.csr -CA ca.crt \
  -CAkey ca.key -set_serial 03 -out server.crt -extfile v3.ext
/usr/bin/cp server.crt ../ssl.crt
apachectl restart

```

That made Chrome happy, but IE didn't like it.  With that server crt the top boxes on IE were all pink and the center one says "certificate error". 

So what is the magic incantation these days to make a CA cert and an unsigned server cert that all of these browsers will accept????

answers.body_markdown:
As mentioned in the comments, `React.useRef` returns an object with the following interface:

```ts
interface ReactRef<T> {
  current: null | T
}
```

where `T` is the type of the value for which you expect to capture a reference. This is mentioned in the docs [here](https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-reference.html#useref).

So the reason `myAudio.play()` isn't working is that you need to access the ref with `myAudio.current.play()`.

It's also advisable to make sure you handle the `null` case doing something like

```js
if (myAudio.current !== null) {
  myAudio.current.play()
}
```

answers.body_markdown:
You really need to spend some time with an R tutorial or two. You have a lot of redundancy (creating a list and then unlisting it) in your code. I'm assuming that you did not mean to drop 95 between 90 and 100 so I start with 5 not 0:

    df <- as.data.frame(matrix(1:100, 20, 5))
    array_name <- "Data:"
    writeLines(array_name, "new_file.txt")
    row.names(df) <- sprintf("%8d:", seq(0, 95, by=5))
    write.fwf(df, 'new_file.txt', append=TRUE ,sep="      ", colnames=FALSE,
         rownames=TRUE, quote=FALSE)

Some of this is just good practice like using <- instead of = makes your code easier to read. Using `FALSE` rather than F. `FALSE` is a reserved word and cannot be reassigned. F is an abbreviation that can be reassigned. If somewhere in your code you accidentally assign a variable F to any value other than 0, your code is broken.

items.body_markdown:
I have a data frame that writes out to a table with a header name at the top. Here's some reproducible code.

    library(gdata)
    df = as.list(c(1:100))
    df = unlist(df)
    dim(df) = c(length(df)/5, 5)
    array_name = as.data.frame(c("Data:"))
    write.fwf(array_name,'new_file.txt',append=T,sep="     ",colnames=F,rownames=F,quote=F)
    write.fwf(df,'new_file.txt',append=T,sep="      ",colnames=F,rownames=F,quote=F)

Here is the output...

    Data:
     1      21      41      61       81
     2      22      42      62       82
     3      23      43      63       83
     4      24      44      64       84
     5      25      45      65       85
     6      26      46      66       86
     7      27      47      67       87
     8      28      48      68       88
     9      29      49      69       89
    10      30      50      70       90

    13      33      53      73       93

    15      35      55      75       95
    16      36      56      76       96
    17      37      57      77       97
    18      38      58      78       98
    19      39      59      79       99
    20      40      60      80      100


How can I make it look like this...

    Data:
            0:        1      21      41      61       81
            5:        2      22      42      62       82
           10:        3      23      43      63       83
           15:        4      24      44      64       84
           20:        5      25      45      65       85
           25:        6      26      46      66       86
           30:        7      27      47      67       87
           35:        8      28      48      68       88
           40:        9      29      49      69       89
           45:       10      30      50      70       90
           50:       11      31      51      71       91
           55:       12      32      52      72       92
           60:       13      33      53      73       93
           65:       14      34      54      74       94
           70:       15      35      55      75       95
           75:       16      36      56      76       96
           80:       17      37      57      77       97
           85:       18      38      58      78       98
           90:       19      39      59      79       99
          100:       20      40      60      80      100

So, Basically I want to: 

1) add the row name column that intervals by 5.

2) make each column line up on the right.

3) shift everything to the right of the header name (lining up with the first digit of the last line - i.e. "100".

Edit/Solution:

This is what I did to solve the problem. I substituted "df" for "G" because that is the variable I was using for my script.

    array_name <- as.data.frame(c("G:"))
    G <- as.list(t(dflist2$`1`[2][!dflist2$`1`[2] == ""]))
    G <- unlist(G)
    dim(G) <- c(length(G)/5, 5)
    G <- as.data.frame(G)
    G <- cbind(row = 0, G)
    for (x in 1:nrow(G)) {
      if (row.names(G[x,]) == "1") {G[x,"row"] = 0
      } else {G[x,"row"] = G[x-1,"row"]+5}
    }
    row.names(G) <- sprintf("   %i:", G$row)
    G <- G[,-1]
    write.fwf(array_name, 'new_file.txt', append = TRUE, sep = "", 
    colnames = FALSE, rownames = FALSE, quote = FALSE)
    write.fwf(G,'new_file.txt',append=TRUE,sep="      ", 
    colnames=FALSE,rownames=TRUE,quote=FALSE)

answers.body_markdown:
Assume an input of 10000 values, where Trouble Sort will give its first error at index 3. Then it was really not worth the effort to have sorted the whole array of 10000 values (twice 5000). It would have been enough to have identified the min and second-min values in both the odd and even series.

The common remedy for such situations, is the use of priority queues, e.g. min-heaps.

So, you could organise the odd and even series into min-heaps, and then start popping values from those until you detect a wrong order.

You could even implement those two heaps in-line (interwoven), without copying the odd/even values into new, dedicated arrays.

[Building a heap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_heap#Building_a_heap) takes *O(n)* when done in buttom-up order and sifting down each subroot.

In the worst case, where Trouble Sort turns out to sort the array correctly, you would have spent *O(nlogn)* time in popping all values from the two heaps, which matches the time complexity you already had.

**This is normal behavior. Because the implementation is wrong.** :(

The reason is that tag `P` is an `inline` element that cannot contain `block` elements, as is the case with tag `H1`.

Change `P` to `DIV`.

See as example: https://jsfiddle.net/ty0uswrm/

Read this documentation: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/dom.html#phrasing-content
